Learning

Abstract

Federated learning involves training statistical models in massive, heterogeneous networks. Naively minimizing an aggregate loss function in such a network may disproportionately advantage or disadvantage some of the devices. In this work, we propose qğ‘q-Fair Federated Learning (qğ‘q-FFL), a novel optimization objective inspired by fair resource allocation in wireless networks that encourages a more fair (specifically, a more uniform) accuracy distribution across devices in federated networks. To solve qğ‘q-FFL, we devise a communication-efficient method, qğ‘q-FedAvg, that is suited to federated networks. We validate both the effectiveness of qğ‘q-FFL and the efficiency of qğ‘q-FedAvg on a suite of federated datasets with both convex and non-convex models, and show that qğ‘q-FFL (along with qğ‘q-FedAvg) outperforms existing baselines in terms of the resulting fairness, flexibility, and efficiency.

1 Introduction

Federated learning is an attractive paradigm for fitting a model to data generated by, and residing on, a network of remote devicesÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Unfortunately, naively minimizing an aggregate loss in a large network may disproportionately advantage or disadvantage the model performance on some of the devices. For example, although the accuracy may be high on average, there is no accuracy guarantee for individual devices in the network. This is exacerbated by the fact that the data are often heterogeneous in federated networks both in terms of size and distribution, and model performance can thus vary widely. In this work, we therefore ask: Can we devise an efficient federated optimization method to encourage a more fair (i.e., more uniform) distribution of the model performance across devices in federated networks?

There has been tremendous recent interest in developing fair methods for machine learningÂ (see, e.g., Cotter etÂ al., 2019; Dwork etÂ al., 2012). However, current approaches do not adequately address concerns in the federated setting. For example, a common definition in the fairness literature is to enforce accuracy parity between protected groups111While fairness is typically concerned with performance between â€œgroupsâ€, we define fairness in the federated setting at a more granular scale in terms of the devices in the network. We note that devices may naturally combine to form groups, and thus use these terms interchangeably in the context of prior work.Â (Zafar etÂ al., 2017a). For devices in massive federated networks, however, it does not make sense for the accuracy to be identical on each device given the significant variability of data in the network. Recent work has taken a step towards addressing this by introducing good-intent fairness, in which the goal is instead to ensure that the training procedure does not overfit a model to any one device at the expense of anotherÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019). However, the proposed objective is rigid in the sense that it only maximizes the performance of the worst performing device/group, and has only be tested in small networks (for 2-3 devices). In realistic federated learning applications, it is natural to instead seek methods that can flexibly trade off between overall performance and fairness in the network, and can be implemented at scale across hundreds to millions of devices.

In this work, we propose qğ‘q-FFL, a novel optimization objective that addresses fairness issues in federated learning. Inspired by work in fair resource allocation for wireless networks, qğ‘q-FFL minimizes an aggregate reweighted loss parameterized by qğ‘q such that the devices with higher loss are given higher relative weight. We show that this objective encourages a device-level definition of fairness in the federated setting, which generalizes standard accuracy parity by measuring the degree of uniformity in performance across devices. As a motivating example, we examine the test

accuracy distribution of a model trained via a baseline approach (FedAvg) vs. qğ‘q-FFL in FigureÂ 1. Due to the variation in the data across devices, the model accuracy is quite poor on some devices. By using qğ‘q-FFL, we can maintain the same overall average accuracy while ensuring a more fair/uniform quality of service across the network. Adaptively minimizing our qğ‘q-FFL objective results in a flexible framework that can be tuned depending on the desired amount of fairness.

To solve qğ‘q-FFL in massive federated networks, we additionally propose a lightweight and scalable distributed method, qğ‘q-FedAvg. Our method carefully accounts for important characteristics of the federated setting such as communication-efficiency and low participation of devicesÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019; McMahan etÂ al., 2017). The method also reduces the overhead of tuning the hyperparameter qğ‘q in qğ‘q-FFL by dynamically estimating the step-sizes associated with different values of qğ‘q.

Through extensive experiments on federated datasets with both convex and non-convex models, we demonstrate the fairness and flexibility of qğ‘q-FFL and the efficiency of qğ‘q-FedAvg compared with existing baselines. In terms of fairness, qğ‘q-FFL is able to reduce the variance of accuracies across devices by 45% on average while maintaining the same overall average accuracy. In terms of efficiency, our distributed method, qğ‘q-FedAvg, is capable of solving the proposed objective orders-of-magnitude more quickly than other baselines. Finally, while we consider our approaches primarily in the context of federated learning, we also demonstrate that qğ‘q-FFL can be applied to other related problems such as meta-learning, helping to produce fair initializations across multiple tasks.

2 Related Work

Fairness in Resource Allocation. Fair resource allocation has been extensively studied in fields such as network managementÂ (Ee & Bajcsy, 2004; Hahne, 1991; Kelly etÂ al., 1998; Neely etÂ al., 2008) and wireless communicationsÂ (Eryilmaz & Srikant, 2006; Nandagopal etÂ al., 2000; Sanjabi etÂ al., 2014; Shi etÂ al., 2014). In these contexts, the problem is defined as allocating a scarce shared resource, e.g., communication time or power, among many users. In these cases, directly maximizing utilities such as total throughput may lead to unfair allocations where some users receive poor service. As a service provider, it is important to improve the quality of service for all users while maintaining overall throughput. For this reason, several popular fairness measurements have been proposed to balance between fairness and total throughput, including Jainâ€™s indexÂ (Jain etÂ al., 1984), entropyÂ (RÃ©nyi etÂ al., 1961), max-min/min-max fairnessÂ (Radunovic & LeÂ Boudec, 2007), and proportional fairnessÂ (Kelly, 1997). A unified framework is captured through Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairnessÂ (Lan etÂ al., 2010; Mo & Walrand, 2000), in which the network manager can tune the emphasis on fairness by changing a single parameter, Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

To draw an analogy between federated learning and the problem of resource allocation, one can think of the global model as a resource that is meant to serve the users (or devices). In this sense, it is natural to ask similar questions about the fairness of the service that users receive and use similar tools to promote fairness. Despite this, we are unaware of any works that use Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness from resource allocation to modify objectives in machine learning. Inspired by the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness metric, we propose a similarly modified objective, qğ‘q-Fair Federated Learning (qğ‘q-FFL), to encourage a more fair accuracy distribution across devices in the context of federated training. Similar to the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness metric, our qğ‘q-FFL objective is flexible enough to enable trade-offs between fairness and other traditional metrics such as accuracy by changing the parameter qğ‘q. In SectionÂ 4, we show empirically that the use of qğ‘q-FFL as an objective in federated learning enables a more uniform accuracy distribution across devicesâ€”significantly reducing variance while maintaining the average accuracy.

Fairness in Machine Learning. Fairness is a broad topic that has received much attention in the machine learning community, though the goals often differ from that described in this work. Indeed, fairness in machine learning is typically defined as the protection of some specific attribute(s). Two common approaches are to preprocess the data to remove information about the protected attribute, or to post-process the model by adjusting the prediction threshold after classifiers are trainedÂ (Feldman, 2015; Hardt etÂ al., 2016; Calmon etÂ al., 2017). Another set of works optimize an objective subject to some fairness constraints during training timeÂ (Agarwal etÂ al., 2018; Cotter etÂ al., 2019; Hashimoto etÂ al., 2018; Woodworth etÂ al., 2017; Baharlouei etÂ al., 2020; Zafar etÂ al., 2017a; b; Dwork etÂ al., 2012). Our work also enforces fairness during training, although we define fairness as the uniformity of the accuracy distribution across devices in federated learning (SectionÂ 3), as opposed to the protection of a specific attribute. Although some works define accuracy parity to enforce equal error rates among specific groups as a notion of fairnessÂ (Zafar etÂ al., 2017a; Cotter etÂ al., 2019), devices in federated networks may not be partitioned by protected attributes, and our goal is not to optimize for identical accuracy across all devices. Cotter etÂ al. (2019) use a notion of â€˜minimum accuracyâ€™, which is conceptually similar to our goal. However, it requires one optimization constraint for each device, which would result in hundreds to millions of constraints in federated networks.

In federated settings,Â Mohri etÂ al. (2019) recently proposed a minimax optimization scheme, Agnostic Federated Learning (AFL), which optimizes for the performance of the single worst device. This method has only been applied at small scales (for a handful of devices). Compared to AFL, our proposed objective is more flexible as it can be tuned based on the desired amount of fairness; AFL can in fact be seen as a special case of our objective, qğ‘q-FFL, with large enough qğ‘q. In SectionÂ 4, we demonstrate that the flexibility of our objective results in more favorable accuracy vs. fairness trade-offs than AFL, and that qğ‘q-FFL can also be solved at scale more efficiently.

Federated Optimization. Federated learning faces challenges such as expensive communication, variability in systems environments in terms of hardware or network connection, and non-identically distributed data across devicesÂ (Li etÂ al., 2019). In order to reduce communication and tolerate heterogeneity, optimization methods must be developed to allow for local updating and low participation among devicesÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Smith etÂ al., 2017). We incorporate these key ingredients when designing methods to solve our qğ‘q-FFL objective efficiently in the federated setting (SectionÂ 3.3).

3 Fair Federated Learning

In this section, we first formally define the classical federated learning objective and methods, and introduce our proposed notion of fairness (Section 3.1). We then introduce qğ‘q-FFL, a novel objective that encourages a more fair (uniform) accuracy distribution across all devices (Section 3.2). Finally, in Section 3.3, we describe qğ‘q-FedAvg, an efficient distributed method to solve the qğ‘q-FFL objective in federated settings.

3.1 Preliminaries: Federated Learning, FedAvg, and fairness

Federated learning algorithms involve hundreds to millions of remote devices learning locally on their device-generated data and communicating with a central server periodically to reach a global consensus. In particular, the goal is typically to solve:

where mğ‘šm is the total number of devices, pkâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0p_{k}\geq 0, and âˆ‘kpk=1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1\sum_{k}p_{k}=1. The local objective Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k}â€™s can be defined by empirical risks over local data, i.e., Fkâ€‹(w)=1nkâ€‹âˆ‘jk=1nkljkâ€‹(w)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘™subscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘¤F_{k}(w)=\frac{1}{n_{k}}\sum_{j_{k}=1}^{n_{k}}l_{j_{k}}(w), where nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} is the number of samples available locally. We can set pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} to be nknsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘›\frac{n_{k}}{n}, where n=âˆ‘knkğ‘›subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n=\sum_{k}n_{k} is the total number of samples to fit a traditional empirical risk minimization-type objective over the entire dataset.

Most prior work solves (1) by sampling a subset of devices with probabilities pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} at each round, and then running an optimizer such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD) for a variable number of iterations locally on each device. These local updating methods enable flexible and efficient communication compared to traditional mini-batch methods, which would simply calculate a subset of the gradientsÂ (Stich, 2019; Wang & Joshi, 2018; Woodworth etÂ al., 2018; Yu etÂ al., 2019). FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), summarized in Algorithm 3 in AppendixÂ C.1, is one of the leading methods to solve (1) in non-convex settings. The method runs simply by having each selected device apply Eğ¸E epochs of SGD locally and then averaging the resulting local models.

Unfortunately, solving problem (1) in this manner can implicitly introduce highly variable performance between different devices. For instance, the learned model may be biased towards devices with larger numbers of data points, or (if weighting devices equally), to commonly occurring devices. More formally, we define our desired fairness criteria for federated learning below.

Definition 1 (Fairness of performance distribution).

For trained models wğ‘¤w and w~~ğ‘¤\tilde{w}, we informally say that model wğ‘¤w provides a more fair solution to the federated learning objective (1) than model w~~ğ‘¤\tilde{w} if the performance of model wğ‘¤w on the mğ‘šm devices, {a1,â€¦â€‹am}subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘š\{a_{1},\dots a_{m}\}, is more uniform than the performance of model w~~ğ‘¤\tilde{w} on the mğ‘šm devices.

In this work, we take â€˜performanceâ€™, aksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜a_{k}, to be the testing accuracy of applying the trained model wğ‘¤w on the test data for device kğ‘˜k. There are many ways to mathematically evaluate the uniformity of the performance. In this work, we mainly use the variance of the performance distribution as a measure of uniformity. However, we also explore other uniformity metrics, both empirically and theoretically, in AppendixÂ A.1. We note that a tension exists between the fairness/uniformity of the final testing accuracy and the average testing accuracy across devices. In general, our goal is to impose more fairness/uniformity while maintaining the same (or similar) average accuracy.

Remark 2 (Connections to other fairness definitions).

Definition 1 targets device-level fairness, which has finer granularity than the classical attribute-level fairness such as accuracy parityÂ (Zafar etÂ al., 2017a). We note that in certain cases where devices can be naturally clustered into groups with specific attributes, our definition can be seen as a relaxed version of accuracy parity, in that we optimize for similar but not necessarily identical performance across devices.

3.2 The objective: qğ‘q-Fair Federated Learning (qğ‘q-FFL)

A natural idea to achieve fairness as defined in (1) would be to reweight the objectiveâ€”assigning higher weights to devices with poor performance, so that the distribution of accuracies in the network shifts towards more uniformity. Note that this reweighting must be done dynamically, as the performance of the devices depends on the model being trained, which cannot be evaluated a priori. Drawing inspiration from Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness, a utility function used in fair resource allocation in wireless networks, we propose the following objective. For given local non-negative cost functions Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} and parameter q>0ğ‘0q>0, we define the qğ‘q-Fair Federated Learning (qğ‘q-FFL) objective as:

minwâ¡fqâ€‹(w)=âˆ‘k=1mpkq+1â€‹Fkq+1â€‹(w),subscriptğ‘¤subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘¤\displaystyle\min_{w}~{}f_{q}(w)=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\frac{p_{k}}{q+1}F_{k}^{q+1}(w)\,, (2)

where Fkq+1â€‹(â‹…)superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1â‹…F_{k}^{q+1}(\cdot) denotes Fkâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜â‹…F_{k}(\cdot) to the power of (q+1)ğ‘1(q\!+\!1). Here, qğ‘q is a parameter that tunes the amount of fairness we wish to impose. Setting q=0ğ‘0q=0 does not encourage fairness beyond the classical federated learning objective (1). A larger qğ‘q means that we emphasize devices with higher local empirical losses, Fkâ€‹(w)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤F_{k}(w), thus imposing more uniformity to the training accuracy distribution and potentially inducing fairness in accordance with DefinitionÂ 1. Setting fqâ€‹(w)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¤f_{q}(w) with a large enough qğ‘q reduces to classical minimax fairnessÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), as the device with the worst performance (largest loss) will dominate the objective. We note that while the (q+1)ğ‘1(q\!+\!1) term in the denominator in (2) may be absorbed in pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}, we include it as it is standard in the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness literature and helps to ease notation. For completeness, we provide additional background on Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness in AppendixÂ B.

As mentioned previously, qğ‘q-FFL generalizes prior work in fair federated learning (AFL)Â (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), allowing for a flexible trade-off between fairness and accuracy as parameterized by qğ‘q. In our theoretical analysis (Appendix A), we provide generalization bounds of qğ‘q-FFL that generalize the learning bounds of the AFL objective. Moreover, based on our fairness definition (Definition 1), we theoretically explore how qğ‘q-FFL results in more uniform accuracy distributions with increasing qğ‘q. Our results suggest that qğ‘q-FFL is able to impose â€˜uniformityâ€™ of the test accuracy distribution in terms of various metrics such as variance and other geometric and information-theoretic measures.

In our experiments (Section 4.2), on both convex and non-convex models, we show that using the qğ‘q-FFL objective, we can obtain fairer/more uniform solutions for federated datasets in terms of both the training and testing accuracy distributions.

3.3 The solver: FedAvg-style qğ‘q-Fair Federated Learning (qğ‘q-FedAvg)

In developing a functional approach for fair federated learning, it is critical to consider not only what objective to solve but also how to solve such an objective efficiently in a massive distributed network. In this section, we provide methods to solve qğ‘q-FFL. We start with a simpler method, qğ‘q-FedSGD, to illustrate our main techniques. We then provide a more efficient counterpart, qğ‘q-FedAvg, by considering local updating schemes. Our proposed methods closely mirror traditional distributed optimization methodsâ€”mini-batch SGD and federated averaging (FedAvg)â€”but with step-sizes and subproblems carefully chosen in accordance with the qğ‘q-FFL problem (2).

Achieving variable levels of fairness: tuning qğ‘q. In devising a method to solve qğ‘q-FFL (2), we begin by noting that it is crucial to first determine how to set qğ‘q. In practice, qğ‘q can be tuned based on the desired amount of fairness (with larger qğ‘q inducing more fairness). As we describe in our experiments (SectionÂ 4.2), it is therefore common to train a family of objectives for different qğ‘q values so that a practitioner can explore the trade-off between accuracy and fairness for the application at hand.

One concern with solving such a family of objectives is that it requires step-size tuning for every value of qğ‘q. In particular, in gradient-based methods, the step-size inversely depends on the Lipschitz constant of the functionâ€™s gradient, which will change as we change qğ‘q. This can quickly cause the search space to explode. To overcome this issue, we propose estimating the local Lipschitz constant for the family of qğ‘q-FFL objectives by using the Lipschitz constant we infer by tuning the step-size (via grid search) on just one qğ‘q (e.g., q=0ğ‘0q=0). This allows us to dynamically adjust the step-size of our gradient-based optimization method for the qğ‘q-FFL objective, avoiding manual tuning for each qğ‘q. In LemmaÂ 3 below we formalize the relation between the Lipschitz constant, Lğ¿L, for q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0.

Lemma 3.

A first approach: qğ‘q-FedSGD. Our first fair federated learning method, qğ‘q-FedSGD, is an extension of the well-known federated mini-batch SGD (FedSGD) methodÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). qğ‘q-FedSGD uses a dynamic step-size instead of the normal fixed step-size of FedSGD. Based on LemmaÂ 3, for each local device kğ‘˜k, the upper-bound of the local Lipschitz constant is Lâ€‹Fkâ€‹(w)q+qâ€‹Fkâ€‹(w)qâˆ’1â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(w)â€–2ğ¿subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤2LF_{k}(w)^{q}+qF_{k}(w)^{q-1}\|\nabla F_{k}(w)\|^{2}. In each step of qğ‘q-FedSGD, âˆ‡Fkâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\nabla F_{k} and Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} on each selected device kğ‘˜k are computed at the current iterate and communicated to the central node. This information is used to compute the step-sizes (weights) for combining the updates from each device. The details are summarized in AlgorithmÂ 1. Note that qğ‘q-FedSGD is reduced to FedSGD when q=0ğ‘0q=0. It is also important to note that to run qğ‘q-FedSGD with different values of qğ‘q, we only need to estimate Lğ¿L once by tuning the step-size on q=0ğ‘0q=0 and can then reuse it for all values of q>0ğ‘0q>0.

Improving communication-efficiency: qğ‘q-FedAvg. In federated settings, communication-efficient schemes using local stochastic solvers (such as FedAvg) have been shown to significantly improve convergence speedÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). However, when q>0ğ‘0q>0, the Fkq+1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1F_{k}^{q+1} term is not an empirical average of the loss over all local samples due to the q+1ğ‘1q+1 exponent, preventing the use of local SGD as in FedAvg. To address this, we propose to generalize FedAvg for q>0ğ‘0q>0 using a more sophisticated dynamic weighted averaging scheme. The weights (step-sizes) are inferred from the upper bound of the local Lipschitz constants of the gradients of Fkq+1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1F_{k}^{q+1}, similar to qğ‘q-FedSGD. To extend the local updating technique of FedAvg to the qğ‘q-FFL objective (2), we propose a heuristic where we replace the gradient âˆ‡Fkâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\nabla F_{k} in the qğ‘q-FedSGD steps with the local updates that are obtained by running SGD locally on device kğ‘˜k. Similarly, qğ‘q-FedAvg is reduced to FedAvg when q=0ğ‘0q=0. We provide additional details on qğ‘q-FedAvg in AlgorithmÂ 2. As we will see empirically, qğ‘q-FedAvg can solve qğ‘q-FFL objective much more efficiently than qğ‘q-FedSGD due to the local updating heuristic. Finally, recall that as qâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘q\to\infty the qğ‘q-FFL objective recovers that of the AFL. However, we empirically notice that qğ‘q-FedAvg has a more favorable convergence speed compared to AFL while resulting in similar performance across devices (see Figure 9 in the appendix).

4 Evaluation

We now present empirical results of the proposed objective, qğ‘q-FFL, and proposed methods, qğ‘q-FedAvg and qğ‘q-FedSGD. We describe our experimental setup in Section 4.1. We then demonstrate the improved fairness of qğ‘q-FFL in Section 4.2, and compare qğ‘q-FFL with several baseline fairness objectives in Section 4.3. Finally, we show the efficiency of qğ‘q-FedAvg compared with qğ‘q-FedSGD in Section 4.4. All code, data, and experiments are publicly available at github.com/litian96/fair_flearn.

4.1 Experimental setup

Federated datasets. We explore a suite of federated datasets using both convex and non-convex models in our experiments. The datasets are curated from prior work in federated learningÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Smith etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020; Mohri etÂ al., 2019) as well as recent federated learning benchmarksÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018). In particular, we study: (1) a synthetic dataset using a linear regression classifier, (2) a Vehicle dataset collected from a distributed sensor networkÂ (Duarte & Hu, 2004) with a linear SVM for binary classification, (3) tweet data curated from Sentiment140Â (Go etÂ al., 2009) (Sent140) with an LSTM classifier for text sentiment analysis, and (4) text data built from The Complete Works of William ShakespeareÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) and an RNN to predict the next character. When comparing with AFL, we use the two small benchmark datasets (Fashion MNISTÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2017) and AdultÂ (Blake, 1998)) studied inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019). When applying qğ‘q-FFL to meta-learning, we use the common meta-learning benchmark dataset OmniglotÂ (Lake etÂ al., 2015). Full dataset details are given in Appendix D.1.

Implementation. We implement all code in TensorflowÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016), simulating a federated network with one server and mğ‘šm devices, where mğ‘šm is the total number of devices in the dataset (Appendix D.1). We provide full details (including all hyperparameter values) in AppendixÂ D.2.

4.2 Fairness of qğ‘q-FFL

In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (DefinitionÂ 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0ğ‘0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0ğ‘0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0ğ‘0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, qğ‘q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average. We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in TableÂ 5 in the appendix, and show that qğ‘q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In TableÂ 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

Choosing qğ‘q. As discussed in SectionÂ 3.3, a natural question is to determine how qğ‘q should be tuned in the qğ‘q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose qğ‘q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of qğ‘qâ€™s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E. In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple qğ‘qâ€™s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data. Rather than using just one optimal qğ‘q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of qğ‘q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of qğ‘q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

4.3 Comparison with other objectives

Next, we compare qğ‘q-FFL with other objectives that are likely to impose fairness in federated networks. One heuristic is to weight each data point equally, which reduces to the original objective in (1) (i.e., qğ‘q-FFL with q=0ğ‘0q=0) and has been investigated in Section 4.2. We additionally compare with two alternatives: weighting devices equally when sampling devices, and weighting devices adversarially, namely, optimizing for the worst-performing device, as proposed inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019).

Weighting devices equally. We compare qğ‘q-FFL with uniform sampling schemes and report testing accuracy in Figure 3. A table with the final accuracies and three fairness metrics is given in the appendix in TableÂ 9. While the â€˜weighting each device equallyâ€™ heuristic tends to outperform our method in training accuracy distributions (Figure 7 and Table 8 in Appendix E), we see that our method produces more fair solutions in terms of testing accuracies. One explanation for this is that uniform sampling is a static method and can easily overfit to devices with very few data points, whereas qğ‘q-FFL will put less weight on a device once its loss becomes small, potentially providing better generalization performance due to its dynamic nature.

Weighting devices adversarially. We further compare with AFLÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), which is the only work we are aware of that aims to address fairness issues in federated learning. We implement a non-stochastic version of AFL where all devices are selected and updated each round, and perform grid search on the AFL hyperparameters, Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} and Î³Î»subscriptğ›¾ğœ†\gamma_{\lambda}. In order to devise a setup that is as favorable to AFL as possible, we modify Algorithm 2 by sampling all devices and letting each of them run gradient descent at each round. We use the same small datasets (AdultÂ (Blake, 1998) and subsampled Fashion MNISTÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2017)) and the same logistic regression model as inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019). Full details of the implementation and hyperparameters (e.g., values of q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} and q2subscriptğ‘2q_{2}) are provided in AppendixÂ D.2.3. We note that, as opposed to AFL, qğ‘q-FFL is flexible depending on the amount of fairness desired, with larger qğ‘q leading to more accuracy uniformity. As discussed, qğ‘q-FFL generalizes AFL in this regard, as AFL is equivalent to qğ‘q-FFL with a large enough qğ‘q. In Table 2, we observe that qğ‘q-FFL can in fact achieve higher testing accuracy than AFL on the device with the worst performance (i.e., the problem that the AFL was designed to solve) with appropriate qğ‘q. This also indicates that qğ‘q-FFL obtains the most fair solutions in certain cases. We also observe that qğ‘q-FFL converges faster in terms of communication rounds compared with AFL to obtain similar performance (AppendixÂ E), which we speculate is due to the non-smoothness of the AFL objective.

4.4 Efficiency of the method qğ‘q-FedAvg

In this section, we show the efficiency of our proposed distributed solver, qğ‘q-FedAvg, by comparing Algorithm 2 with its non-local-updating baseline qğ‘q-FedSGD (Algorithm 1) to solve the same objective (same q>0ğ‘0q>0 as in Table 1). At each communication round, we have each method perform the same amount of computation, with qğ‘q-FedAvg running one epoch of local updates on each selected device while qğ‘q-FedSGD runs gradient descent with the local training data. In FigureÂ 4, qğ‘q-FedAvg converges faster than qğ‘q-FedSGD in terms of communication rounds in most cases due to its local updating scheme. The slower convergence of qğ‘q-FedAvg compared with qğ‘q-FedSGD on the synthetic dataset may be due to the fact that when local data distributions are highly heterogeneous, local updating schemes may allow local models to move too far away from the initial global model, potentially hurting convergence; see Figure 10 in Appendix E for more details.

To demonstrate the optimality of our dynamic step-size strategy in terms of solving qğ‘q-FFL, we also compare our solver qğ‘q-FedSGD with FedSGD with a best-tuned step-size. For qğ‘q-FedSGD, we tune a step-size on q=0ğ‘0q=0 and apply that step-size to solve qğ‘q-FFL with q>0ğ‘0q>0. qğ‘q-FedSGD has similar performance with FedSGD, which indicates that (the inverse of) our estimated Lipschitz constant on q>0ğ‘0q>0 is as good as a best tuned fixed step-size. We can reuse this estimation for different qğ‘qâ€™s instead of manually re-tuning it when qğ‘q changes. We show the full results on other datasets in Appendix E. We note that both proposed methods qğ‘q-FedAvg and qğ‘q-FedSGD can be easily integrated into existing implementations of federated learning algorithms such as TensorFlow FederatedÂ (TFF, ).

4.5 Beyond federated learning: Applying qğ‘q-FFL to meta-learning

Finally, we generalize the proposed qğ‘q-FFL objective to other learning tasks beyond federated learning. One natural extension is to apply qğ‘q-FFL to meta-learning, where each task can be viewed as a device in federated networks. The goal of meta-learning is to learn a model initialization such that it can be quickly adapted to new tasks using limited training samples. However, as the new tasks can be heterogeneous, the performance distribution of the final personalized models may also be non-uniform. Therefore, we aim to learn a better initialization such that it can quickly solve unseen tasks in a fair manner, i.e., reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution of the personalized models.

Dataset Objective Average Worst 10% Best 10% Variance
(%) (%) (%)
Omniglot q=0ğ‘0q=0 79.1 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 9.8 61.2 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 3.2 94.0 Â±plus-or-minus\pm .5 93 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 23

To achieve this goal, we propose a new method, qğ‘q-MAML, by combining qğ‘q-FFL with the popular meta-learning method MAMLÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017). In particular, instead of updating the global model in the way described in MAML, we update the global parameters using the gradients of the qğ‘q-FFL objective 1q+1â€‹Fkq+1â€‹(w)1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘¤\frac{1}{q+1}F_{k}^{q+1}(w), with weights inferred from LemmaÂ 3. Similarly, qğ‘q-MAML with q=0ğ‘0q=0 reduces to MAML, and qğ‘q-MAML with qâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘q\to\infty corresponds to MAML with a most â€˜fairâ€™ initialization and a potentially lower average accuracy. The detailed algorithm is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 4 in AppendixÂ C.2. We sample 10 tasks at each round during meta-training, and train for 5 iterations of (mini-batch) SGD for personalization on meta-testing tasks. We report test accuracy of personalized models on the meta-testing tasks. From Figure 5 and Table 3 above, we observe that qğ‘q-MAML is able to learn initializations which result in fairer personalized models with lower variance.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we propose qğ‘q-FFL, a novel optimization objective inspired by fair resource allocation in wireless networks that encourages fairer (more uniform) accuracy distributions across devices in federated learning. We devise a scalable method, qğ‘q-FedAvg, to solve this objective in massive networks. Our empirical evaluation on a suite of federated datasets demonstrates the resulting fairness and flexibility of qğ‘q-FFL, as well as the efficiency of qğ‘q-FedAvg compared with existing baselines. We show that our framework is useful not only for federated learning tasks, but also for other learning paradigms such as meta-learning.

Appendix A Theoretical Analysis of the proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL

A.1 uniformity induced by qğ‘q-FFL

In this section, we theoretically justify that the qğ‘q-FFL objective can impose more uniformity of the performance/accuracy distribution. As discussed in Section 3.2, qğ‘q-FFL can encourage more fair solutions in terms of several metrics, including (1) the variance of accuracy distribution (smaller variance), (2) the cosine similarity between the accuracy distribution and the all-ones vector ğŸ1\bf{1} (larger similarity), and (3) the entropy of the accuracy distribution (larger entropy). We begin by formally defining these fairness notions.

To enforce uniformity/fairness (defined in DefinitionÂ 4, 5, and 6), we propose the qğ‘q-FFL objective to impose more weights on the devices with worse performance. Throughout the proof, for the ease of mathematical exposition, we consider a similar unweighted objective:

We first investigate the special case of q=1ğ‘1q=1 and show that q=1ğ‘1q=1 results in more fair solutions than q=0ğ‘0q=0 based on DefinitionÂ 4 and DefinitionÂ 5.

Lemma 7.

Lemma 11 (Equivalence between uniformity in entropy and cosine distance).

A.2 Generalization bounds

In this section, we first describe the setup we consider in more detail, and then provide generalization bounds of qğ‘q-FFL. One benefit of qğ‘q-FFL is that it allows for a flexible trade-off between fairness and accuracy, which generalizes AFL (a special case of qğ‘q-FFL with qâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘q\to\infty). We also provide learning bounds that generalize the bounds of the AFL objective, as described below.

Appendix B Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness and qğ‘q-FFL

As discussed in SectionÂ 2, while it is natural to consider the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness framework for machine learning, we are unaware of any work that uses Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness to modify machine learning training objectives. We provide additional details on the framework below; for further background on Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairness and fairness in resource allocation more generally, we defer the reader toÂ Shi etÂ al. (2014); Mo & Walrand (2000).

Î±ğ›¼\alpha-fairnessÂ (Lan etÂ al., 2010; Mo & Walrand, 2000) is a popular fairness metric widely-used in resource allocation problems. The framework defines a family of overall utility functions that can be derived by summing up the following function of the individual utilities of the users in the network:

UÎ±â€‹(x)={lnâ¡(x),ifâ€‹Î±=111âˆ’Î±â€‹x1âˆ’Î±,ifâ€‹Î±â‰¥0,Î±â‰ 1.subscriptğ‘ˆğ›¼ğ‘¥casesğ‘¥ifğ›¼111ğ›¼superscriptğ‘¥1ğ›¼formulae-sequenceifğ›¼0ğ›¼1\displaystyle U_{\alpha}(x)=\begin{cases}\ln(x),&\text{if}\ \alpha=1\\ \frac{1}{1-\alpha}x^{1-\alpha},&\text{if}\ \alpha\geq 0,\alpha\neq 1\,.\end{cases}

Here UÎ±â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ˆğ›¼ğ‘¥U_{\alpha}(x) represents the individual utility of some specific user given xğ‘¥x allocated resources (e.g., bandwidth). The goal is to find a resource allocation strategy to maximize the sum of the individual utilities. This family of functions includes a wide range of popular fair resource allocation strategies. In particular, the above function represents zero fairness with Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, proportional fairnessÂ (Kelly, 1997) with Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1, harmonic mean fairnessÂ (Dashti etÂ al., 2013) with Î±=2ğ›¼2\alpha=2, and max-min fairnessÂ (Radunovic & LeÂ Boudec, 2007) with Î±=+âˆğ›¼\alpha=+\infty.

Note that in federated learning, we are dealing with costs and not utilities. Thus, max-min in resource allocation corresponds to min-max in our setting. With this analogy, it is clear that in our proposed objective qğ‘q-FFL (2), the case where q=+âˆğ‘q=+\infty corresponds to min-max fairness since it is optimizing for the worst-performing device, similar to what was proposed inÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019). Also, q=0ğ‘0q=0 corresponds to zero fairness, which reduces to the original FedAvg objective (1). In resource allocation problems, Î±ğ›¼\alpha can be tuned for trade-offs between fairness and system efficiency. In federated settings, qğ‘q can be tuned based on the desired level of fairness (e.g., desired variance of accuracy distributions) and other performance metrics such as the overall accuracy. For instance, in Table 2 in Section 4.3, we demonstrate on two datasets that as qğ‘q increases, the overall average accuracy decreases slightly while the worst accuracies are increased significantly and the variance of the accuracy distribution decreases.

D.1 Datasets and Models

We provide full details on the datasets and models used in our experiments. The statistics of four federated datasets used in federated learning (as opposed to meta-learning) experiments are summarized in Table 4. We report the total number of devices, the total number of samples, and mean and deviation in the sizes of total data points on each device. Additional details on the datasets and models are described below.

  • â€¢

    Synthetic: We follow a similar set up as that inÂ Shamir etÂ al. (2014) and impose additional heterogeneity. The model is y=argmax(softmax(Wx+b))y=\textrm{\emph{argmax}(softmax}(Wx+b)), xâˆˆâ„60,Wâˆˆâ„10Ã—60,bâˆˆâ„10formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptâ„60formulae-sequenceğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„1060ğ‘superscriptâ„10x\in\mathbb{R}^{60},W\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 60},b\in\mathbb{R}^{10}, and the goal is to learn a global Wğ‘ŠW and bğ‘b. Samples (Xk,Yk)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜(X_{k},Y_{k}) and local models on each device kğ‘˜k satisfies Wkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(uk,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜ğ’©subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜1W_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(u_{k},1), bkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(uk,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ’©subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜1b_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(u_{k},1), ukâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ’©01u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1); xkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(vk,Î£)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ’©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜Î£x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(v_{k},\Sigma), where the covariance matrix Î£Î£\Sigma is diagonal with Î£j,j=jâˆ’1.2subscriptÎ£ğ‘—ğ‘—superscriptğ‘—1.2\Sigma_{j,j}=j^{-1.2}. There are 100 devices in total and the number of samples on each devices follows a power law.

  • â€¢

    Vehicle222http://www.ecs.umass.edu/~mduarte/Software.html: We use the same Vehicle Sensor (Vehicle) dataset asÂ Smith etÂ al. (2017), modelling each sensor as a device. This dataset consists of acoustic, seismic, and infrared sensor data collected from a distributed network of 23 sensorsÂ Duarte & Hu (2004). Each sample has a 100-dimension feature and a binary label. We train a linear SVM to predict between AAV-type and DW-type vehicles. We tune the hyperparameters in SVM and report the best configuration.

  • â€¢

    Sent140: This dataset is a collection of tweets curated from 1,101 accounts from Sentiment140Â (Go etÂ al., 2009) (Sent140) where each Twitter account corresponds to a device. The task is text sentiment analysis which we model as a binary classification problem. The model takes as input a 25-word sequence, embeds each word into a 300-dimensional space using pretrained GloveÂ (Pennington etÂ al., 2014), and outputs a binary label after two LSTM layers and one densely-connected layer.

  • â€¢

    Shakespeare: This dataset is built from The Complete Works of William ShakespeareÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Each speaking role in the plays is associated with a device. We subsample 31 speaking roles to train a deep language model for next character prediction. The model takes as input an 80-character sequence, embeds each character into a learnt 8-dimensional space, and outputs one character after two LSTM layers and one densely-connected layer.

  • â€¢

    Omniglot: The Omniglot datasetÂ (Lake etÂ al., 2015) consists of 1,623 characters from 50 different alphabets. We create 300 meta-training tasks from the first 1,200 characters, and 100 meta-testing tasks from the last 423 characters. Each task is a 5-class classification problem where each character forms a class. The model is a convolutional neural network with two convolution layers and two fully-connected layers.

D.2 Implementation Details

D.2.1 Machines

We simulate the federated setting (one server and mğ‘šm devices) on a server with 2 IntelÂ®Â®{}^{\text{\textregistered}} XeonÂ®Â®{}^{\text{\textregistered}} E5-2650 v4 CPUs and 8 NVidiaÂ®Â®{}^{\text{\textregistered}} 1080Ti GPUs.

D.2.2 Software

We implement all code in TensorFlowÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016) Version 1.10.1. Please see github.com/litian96/fair_flearn for full details.

D.2.3 Hyperparameters

We randomly split data on each local device into 80% training set, 10% testing set, and 10% validation set. We tune a best qğ‘q from {0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1,2,5,10,15}0.0010.010.10.51251015\{0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1,2,5,10,15\} on the validation set and report accuracy distributions on the testing set. We pick up the qğ‘q value where the variance decreases the most, while the overall average accuracy change (compared with the q=0ğ‘0q=0 case) is within 1%. For each dataset, we repeat this process for five randomly selected train/test/validation splits, and report the mean and standard deviation across these five runs where applicable. For Synthetic, Vehicle, Sent140, and Shakespeare, optimal qğ‘q values are 1, 5, 1, and 0.001, respectively. For all datasets, we randomly sample 10 devices each round. We tune the learning rate and batch size on FedAvg and use the same learning rate and batch size for all qğ‘q-FedAvg experiments of that dataset. The learning rates for Synthetic, Vehicle, Sent140, and Shakespeare are 0.1, 0.01, 0.03, and 0.8, respectively. The batch sizes for Synthetic, Vehicle, Sent140, and Shakespeare are 10, 64, 32, and 10. The number of local epochs Eğ¸E is fixed to be 1 for both FedAvg and qğ‘q-FedAvg regardless of the values of qğ‘q.

In comparing qğ‘q-FedAvgâ€™s efficiency with qğ‘q-FedSGD, we also tune a best learning rate for qğ‘q-FedSGD methods on q=0ğ‘0q=0. For each comparison, we fix devices selected and mini-batch orders across all runs. We stop training when the training loss Fâ€‹(w)ğ¹ğ‘¤F(w) does not decrease for 10 rounds. When running AFL methods, we search for a best Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} and Î³Î»subscriptğ›¾ğœ†\gamma_{\lambda} such that AFL achieves the highest testing accuracy on the device with the highest loss within a fixed number of rounds. For Adult, we use Î³w=0.1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤0.1\gamma_{w}=0.1 and Î³Î»=0.1subscriptğ›¾ğœ†0.1\gamma_{\lambda}=0.1; for Fashion MNIST, we use Î³w=0.001subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤0.001\gamma_{w}=0.001 and Î³Î»=0.01subscriptğ›¾ğœ†0.01\gamma_{\lambda}=0.01. We use the same Î³wsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¤\gamma_{w} as step-sizes for qğ‘q-FedAvg on Adult and Fashion MNIST. In Table 2, q1=0.01,q2=2formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘10.01subscriptğ‘22q_{1}=0.01,q_{2}=2 for qğ‘q-FFL on Adult and q1=5,q2=15formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘15subscriptğ‘215q_{1}=5,q_{2}=15 for qğ‘q-FFL on Fashion MNIST. Similarly, the number of local epochs is fixed to 1 whenever we perform local updates.

Appendix E Full Experiments

E.1 Full results of previous experiments

Fairness of qğ‘q-FFL under all uniformity metrics.

We demonstrate the fairness of qğ‘q-FFL in TableÂ 1 in terms of variance. Here, we report similar results in terms of other uniformity measures (the last two columns).

Fairness of qğ‘q-FFL with respect to training accuracy.

The empirical results in SectionÂ 4 are with respect to testing accuracy. As a sanity check, we show that qğ‘q-FFL also results in more fair training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6.

Average testing accuracy with respect to devices.

In Section 4.2, we show that qğ‘q-FFL leads to more fair accuracy distributions while maintaining approximately the same testing accuracies. Note that we report average testing accuracy with respect to all data points in Table 1. However, we observe similar results on average accuracy with respect to all devices between q=0ğ‘0q=0 and q>0ğ‘0q>0 objectives, as shown in Table 7. This indicates that qğ‘q-FFL can reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution without sacrificing the average accuracy over devices or over data points.

Comparison with uniform sampling.

In Figure 7 and Table 8, we show that in terms of training accuracies, the uniform sampling heuristic may outperform qğ‘q-FFL (as opposed to the testing accuracy results in SectionÂ 4). We suspect that this is because the uniform sampling baseline is a static method and is likely to overfit to those devices with few samples. In additional to Figure 3 in SectionÂ 4.3, we also report the average testing accuracy with respect to data points, best 10%, worst 10% accuracies, and the variance (along with two other uniformity measures) in Table 9.

E.2 Additional Experiments

Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. To study how data heterogeneity and the total number of devices affect unfairness in a more direct way, we investigate into a set of synthetic datasets where we can quantify the degree of heterogeneity. The results are shown in TableÂ 10 below. We generate three synthetic datasets following the process described in AppendixÂ D.1, but with different parameters to control heterogeneity. In particular, we generate an IID dataâ€” Synthetic (IID) by setting the same Wğ‘ŠW and bğ‘b on all devices and setting the samples xkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ’©01x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1) for any device kğ‘˜k. We instantiate two non-identically distributed datasets (Synthetic (1, 1) and Synthetic (2, 2)) from Synthetic (Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta) where ukâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î±)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›¼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha) and Bkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î²)similar-tosubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›½B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). Recall that Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta allows to precisely manipulate the degree of heterogeneity with larger Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta values indicating more statistical heterogeneity. Therefore, from top to bottom in TableÂ 10, data are more heterogeneous. For each dataset, we further create two variants with different number of participating devices. We see that as data become more heterogeneous and as the number of devices in the network increases, the accuracy distribution tends to be less uniform.

A family of qğ‘qâ€™s results in variable levels of fairness.

In Table 11, we show the accuracy distribution statistics of using a family of qğ‘qâ€™s on synthetic data. Our objective and methods are not sensitive to any particular qğ‘q since all q>0ğ‘0q>0 values can lead to more fair solutions compared with q=0ğ‘0q=0. In our experiments in Section 4, we report the results using the qğ‘q values selected following the protocol described in Appendix D.2.3.

Device-specific qğ‘q.

In these experiments, we explore a device-specific strategy for selecting qğ‘q in qğ‘q-FFL. We solve qğ‘q-FFL with qâˆˆ{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10}ğ‘00.0010.010.112510q\in\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10\} in parallel. After training, each device selects the best resulting model based on the validation data and tests the performance of the model using the testing set. We report the results in terms of testing accuracy in Table 12. Interestingly, using this device-specific strategy the average accuracy in fact increases while the variance of accuracies is reduced, in comparison with q=0ğ‘0q=0. We note that this strategy does induce more local computation and additional communication load at each round. However, it does not increase the number of communication rounds if run in parallel.

Convergence speed of qğ‘q-FFL.

Since qâˆ’FFLâ€‹(q>0)FFLğ‘0-\texttt{FFL}~{}(q>0) is more difficult to optimize, a natural question one might ask is: will the qğ‘q-FFL q>0ğ‘0q>0 objectives slow the convergence compared with FedAvg? We empirically investigate this on the four datasets. We use qğ‘q-FedAvg to solve qğ‘q-FFL, and compare it with FedAvg (i.e., solving qğ‘q-FFL with q=0ğ‘0q=0). As demonstrated in Figure 8, the qğ‘q values that result in more fair solutions also do not significantly slow down convergence.

Efficiency of qğ‘q-FFL compared with AFL.

One added benefit of qğ‘q-FFL is that it leads to faster convergence than AFLâ€”even when we use non-local-updating methods for both objectives. In Figure 9, we show with respect to the final testing accuracy for the single worst device (i.e., the objective that AFL is trying to optimize), qğ‘q-FFL converges faster than AFL. As the number of devices increases (from Fashion MNIST to Vehicle), the performance gap between AFL and qğ‘q-FFL becomes larger because AFL introduces larger variance.

Efficiency of qğ‘q-FedAvg under different data heterogeneity.

As mentioned in Appendix E.1, one potential cause for the slower convergence of qğ‘q-FedAvg on the synthetic dataset may be that local updating schemes could hurt convergence when local data distributions are highly heterogeneous. Although it has been shown that applying updates locally results in significantly faster convergence in terms of communication roundsÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Smith etÂ al., 2018), which is consistent with our observation on most datasets, we note that when data is highly heterogeneous, local updating may hurt convergence. We validate this by creating an IID synthetic dataset (Synthetic-IID) where local data on each device follow the same global distribution. We call the synthetic dataset used in Section 4 Synthetic-Non-IID. We also create a hybrid dataset (Synthetic-Hybrid) where half of the total devices are assigned IID data from the same distribution, and half of the total devices are assigned data from different distributions. We observe that if data is perfectly IID, qğ‘q-FedAvg is more efficient than qğ‘q-FedSGD. As data become more heterogeneous, qğ‘q-FedAvg converges more slowly than qğ‘q-FedSGD in terms of communication rounds. For all three synthetic datasets, we repeat the process of tuning a best constant step-size for FedSGD and observe similar results as before â€” our dynamic solver qğ‘q-FedSGD behaves similarly (or even outperforms) a best hand-tuned FedSGD.
